natural problem: A fair 6-sided die is rolled.  If I roll $n$, then I win $n^2$ dollars.  What is the expected value of my win?  Express your answer as a dollar value rounded to the nearest cent.
natural solution: Each number from 1 to 6 has probability $\dfrac16$ of being rolled, so the expected value is \begin{align} E &= \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$1^2\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$2^2\right) + \cdots + \left(\dfrac{1}{6} \times \$6^2\right) \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: real and E :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. E n = n powr 2"
and h2 : "prob_space.expectation (\<lambda>n. E n) = 15.17"
shows  "15.17 = (\<Sum>n = 1..6. E n) / 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair 6-sided die is rolled.  If I roll $n$, then I win $n^2$ dollars.  What is the expected value of my win?  Express your answer as a dollar value rounded to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$15.17
 ### Proof
 Each number from 1 to 6 has probability $\dfrac16$ of being rolled, so the expected value is \begin{align} E &= \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$1^2\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$2^2\right) + \cdots + \left(\dfrac{1}{6} \times \$6^2\right) \\
 &= \dfrac{1}{6}(\$1 + \$4 + \$9 + \$16 + \$25 + \$36) \\ &= \$\dfrac{91}{6} \\ & \approx \boxed{\$15.17}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: real and E :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. E n = n powr 2"
and h2 : "prob_space.expectation (\<lambda>n. E n) = 15.17"
shows  "15.17 = (\<Sum>n = 1..6. E n) / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Suppose a function $E(n) = n^2$ for integers $1 \leq n \leq 6$. If the expected value of $E(n)$ is $15.17$, find the average of the values $E(1), E(2), E(3), E(4), E(5),$ and $E(6)$. The final answer is $15.17$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: real and E :: real
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "n \<le> 6"
and h2 : "E = (sum (\<lambda>n. (n powr 2) * (1/6)) {1..6})"
shows  "E = 15.17"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair 6-sided die is rolled.  If I roll $n$, then I win $n^2$ dollars.  What is the expected value of my win?  Express your answer as a dollar value rounded to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$15.17
 ### Proof
 Each number from 1 to 6 has probability $\dfrac16$ of being rolled, so the expected value is \begin{align} E &= \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$1^2\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$2^2\right) + \cdots + \left(\dfrac{1}{6} \times \$6^2\right) \\
 &= \dfrac{1}{6}(\$1 + \$4 + \$9 + \$16 + \$25 + \$36) \\ &= \$\dfrac{91}{6} \\ & \approx \boxed{\$15.17}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: real and E :: real
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "n \<le> 6"
and h2 : "E = (sum (\<lambda>n. (n powr 2) * (1/6)) {1..6})"
shows  "E = 15.17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given that $n$ is a real number between $1$ and $6$ (inclusive), calculate the expected value $E$ of the sum of the squares of each number in the range, multiplied by $\frac{1}{6}$. The final answer is $15.17$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob n :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = 1/6"
and h1 : "n \<in> {1..6}"
and h2 : "win = n powr 2"
shows  "expected_value = (\<Sum>n\<in>{1..6}. prob * win) = 15.17"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair 6-sided die is rolled.  If I roll $n$, then I win $n^2$ dollars.  What is the expected value of my win?  Express your answer as a dollar value rounded to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$15.17
 ### Proof
 Each number from 1 to 6 has probability $\dfrac16$ of being rolled, so the expected value is \begin{align} E &= \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$1^2\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$2^2\right) + \cdots + \left(\dfrac{1}{6} \times \$6^2\right) \\
 &= \dfrac{1}{6}(\$1 + \$4 + \$9 + \$16 + \$25 + \$36) \\ &= \$\dfrac{91}{6} \\ & \approx \boxed{\$15.17}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes prob n :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = 1/6"
and h1 : "n \<in> {1..6}"
and h2 : "win = n powr 2"
shows  "expected_value = (\<Sum>n\<in>{1..6}. prob * win) = 15.17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a game, there is an equal probability of rolling a number from 1 to 6 on a fair six-sided die. If the score of each roll is the square of the number rolled, find the expected value of the score for one roll. The final answer is 15.17.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes expected_value :: real and die_outcomes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (die_outcomes n = n powr 2)"
and h1 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>n = 1..6. (die_outcomes n)) / 6"
shows  "expected_value = 15.17"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair 6-sided die is rolled.  If I roll $n$, then I win $n^2$ dollars.  What is the expected value of my win?  Express your answer as a dollar value rounded to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$15.17
 ### Proof
 Each number from 1 to 6 has probability $\dfrac16$ of being rolled, so the expected value is \begin{align} E &= \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$1^2\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$2^2\right) + \cdots + \left(\dfrac{1}{6} \times \$6^2\right) \\
 &= \dfrac{1}{6}(\$1 + \$4 + \$9 + \$16 + \$25 + \$36) \\ &= \$\dfrac{91}{6} \\ & \approx \boxed{\$15.17}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes expected_value :: real and die_outcomes :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (die_outcomes n = n powr 2)"
and h1 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>n = 1..6. (die_outcomes n)) / 6"
shows  "expected_value = 15.17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Suppose the outcome of a die roll is squared. Calculate the expected value of a single roll, where the die has 6 faces numbered from 1 to 6. The final answer is 15.17.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes E :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "E = (\<lambda>n. n powr 2)"
and h1 : "fair_die (f :: real \<Rightarrow> real)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. 1/6 * E (f n)) {1..6} = 15.17"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair 6-sided die is rolled.  If I roll $n$, then I win $n^2$ dollars.  What is the expected value of my win?  Express your answer as a dollar value rounded to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$15.17
 ### Proof
 Each number from 1 to 6 has probability $\dfrac16$ of being rolled, so the expected value is \begin{align} E &= \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$1^2\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$2^2\right) + \cdots + \left(\dfrac{1}{6} \times \$6^2\right) \\
 &= \dfrac{1}{6}(\$1 + \$4 + \$9 + \$16 + \$25 + \$36) \\ &= \$\dfrac{91}{6} \\ & \approx \boxed{\$15.17}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes E :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "E = (\<lambda>n. n powr 2)"
and h1 : "fair_die (f :: real \<Rightarrow> real)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. 1/6 * E (f n)) {1..6} = 15.17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Suppose there is a fair six-sided die with an unknown function $f$ applied to each outcome. If the expected value of the squared outcome is given by $E(n) = n^2$, find the sum of the expected values for each outcome, given by $\sum_{n=1}^6 \frac{1}{6} E(f(n))$. The final answer is 15.17.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes expected_value :: real
assumes h0 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..6}. (n powr 2) / 6)"
shows  "expected_value = 15.17"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair 6-sided die is rolled.  If I roll $n$, then I win $n^2$ dollars.  What is the expected value of my win?  Express your answer as a dollar value rounded to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$15.17
 ### Proof
 Each number from 1 to 6 has probability $\dfrac16$ of being rolled, so the expected value is \begin{align} E &= \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$1^2\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$2^2\right) + \cdots + \left(\dfrac{1}{6} \times \$6^2\right) \\
 &= \dfrac{1}{6}(\$1 + \$4 + \$9 + \$16 + \$25 + \$36) \\ &= \$\dfrac{91}{6} \\ & \approx \boxed{\$15.17}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes expected_value :: real
assumes h0 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..6}. (n powr 2) / 6)"
shows  "expected_value = 15.17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the expected value of the square of a number rolled on a fair six-sided die. The final answer is 15.17.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes expected_value :: real
assumes h0 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..6}. n powr 2 / 6)"
shows  "expected_value \<approx> 15.17"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair 6-sided die is rolled.  If I roll $n$, then I win $n^2$ dollars.  What is the expected value of my win?  Express your answer as a dollar value rounded to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$15.17
 ### Proof
 Each number from 1 to 6 has probability $\dfrac16$ of being rolled, so the expected value is \begin{align} E &= \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$1^2\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$2^2\right) + \cdots + \left(\dfrac{1}{6} \times \$6^2\right) \\
 &= \dfrac{1}{6}(\$1 + \$4 + \$9 + \$16 + \$25 + \$36) \\ &= \$\dfrac{91}{6} \\ & \approx \boxed{\$15.17}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes expected_value :: real
assumes h0 : "expected_value = (\<Sum>n \<in> {1..6}. n powr 2 / 6)"
shows  "expected_value \<approx> 15.17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Calculate the expected value of the square of the result when rolling a fair 6-sided die. The final answer is approximately 15.17.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "P n = n powr 2"
and h2 : "1 / 6 \<le> P n"
and h3 : "P n \<le> 6 / 6"
shows  "P n = 15.17"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair 6-sided die is rolled.  If I roll $n$, then I win $n^2$ dollars.  What is the expected value of my win?  Express your answer as a dollar value rounded to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$15.17
 ### Proof
 Each number from 1 to 6 has probability $\dfrac16$ of being rolled, so the expected value is \begin{align} E &= \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$1^2\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$2^2\right) + \cdots + \left(\dfrac{1}{6} \times \$6^2\right) \\
 &= \dfrac{1}{6}(\$1 + \$4 + \$9 + \$16 + \$25 + \$36) \\ &= \$\dfrac{91}{6} \\ & \approx \boxed{\$15.17}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "n \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "P n = n powr 2"
and h2 : "1 / 6 \<le> P n"
and h3 : "P n \<le> 6 / 6"
shows  "P n = 15.17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find a number $n$ in the set $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$ such that $P(n) = n^2$ and $\frac{1}{6} \leq P(n) \leq \frac{6}{6}$. The final answer is $15.17$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and E :: real
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "n \<le> 6"
and h2 : "E = (\<Sum> n = 1..6. (n powr 2) * (1 / 6))"
shows  "E = 15.17"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair 6-sided die is rolled.  If I roll $n$, then I win $n^2$ dollars.  What is the expected value of my win?  Express your answer as a dollar value rounded to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$15.17
 ### Proof
 Each number from 1 to 6 has probability $\dfrac16$ of being rolled, so the expected value is \begin{align} E &= \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$1^2\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$2^2\right) + \cdots + \left(\dfrac{1}{6} \times \$6^2\right) \\
 &= \dfrac{1}{6}(\$1 + \$4 + \$9 + \$16 + \$25 + \$36) \\ &= \$\dfrac{91}{6} \\ & \approx \boxed{\$15.17}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int and E :: real
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "n \<le> 6"
and h2 : "E = (\<Sum> n = 1..6. (n powr 2) * (1 / 6))"
shows  "E = 15.17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Calculate the expected value $E$ of the square of an integer $n$ chosen uniformly at random between $1$ and $6$ inclusive. The final answer is $15.17$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes E :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> E n = n powr 2 / 6"
shows  "sum E {1..6} = 15.17"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A fair 6-sided die is rolled.  If I roll $n$, then I win $n^2$ dollars.  What is the expected value of my win?  Express your answer as a dollar value rounded to the nearest cent. The final Answer is \$15.17
 ### Proof
 Each number from 1 to 6 has probability $\dfrac16$ of being rolled, so the expected value is \begin{align} E &= \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$1^2\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{6}\times \$2^2\right) + \cdots + \left(\dfrac{1}{6} \times \$6^2\right) \\
 &= \dfrac{1}{6}(\$1 + \$4 + \$9 + \$16 + \$25 + \$36) \\ &= \$\dfrac{91}{6} \\ & \approx \boxed{\$15.17}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes E :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> E n = n powr 2 / 6"
shows  "sum E {1..6} = 15.17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Calculate the sum of the function $E(n) = \frac{n^2}{6}$ for integers $n$ from $1$ to $6$. The final answer is $15.17$.
